snippet.textDisplay: Having never seen Deus Ex in it's glory days wherein the amount of stuff in it would have creamed a 2000's gamers' pants instantly, I can safely say that It's not the best use of like £2.50 on steam. I don't care that it looks like a bunch of cardboard cutouts chilling in boxy levels with rough textures. What I do care about is the fact that it has no discernable narrative hook. I'm playing this "great game" that feasts off of nostalgia, and currently, having died repeatedly in the second level, any hook that might have drawn me in, is now long since passed and I'm not having fun with it. So far I know that JC Denton is unnecessarily an edgelord and doesn't wear his trenchcoat as well as Adam does, Bob is Bad, Ambrosia is good, NSF is misguided but good, and UNATCO is corrupt. but I'm struggling to care honestly, because I don't know why I'm shooting these guys, I don't care, move me onto the next bit of story already because I can stop playing and play portal 1+2, an objectively better made story-driven game series, or some other games that actually draw me in to what the heck I'm doing. (and no I don't play conventional FPS's) But that's my opinion from a new perspective, nearly 17 years after release.
snippet.textOriginal: Having never seen Deus Ex in it's glory days wherein the amount of stuff in it would have creamed a 2000's gamers' pants instantly, I can safely say that It's not the best use of like £2.50 on steam. I'm playing this "great game" that feasts off of nostalgia, and currently, having died repeatedly in the second level, any hook that might have drawn me in, is now long since passed and I'm not having fun with it. So far I know that JC Denton is unnecessarily an edgelord and doesn't wear his trenchcoat as well as Adam does, Bob is Bad, Ambrosia is good, NSF is misguided but good, and UNATCO is corrupt. but I'm struggling to care honestly, because I don't know why I'm shooting these guys, I don't care, move me onto the next bit of story already because I can stop playing and play portal 1+2, an objectively better made story-driven game series, or some other games that actually draw me in to what the heck I'm doing. (and no I don't play conventional FPS's) But that's my opinion from a new perspective, nearly 17 years after release.

snippet.textDisplay:
+MindstormXL I'm very much part of the minority because I didn't find Invisible War to be too bad. It was quite a bit more casual in comparison and the levels were MUCH smaller. The combat wasn't as satisfying either. But still, I had fun.

I'm sure it would have been a LOT better if they just took the route of developing the game for PC first and then release a modified version for Xbox with restructured maps and assets. I remember the first Far Cry basically did this, and compensated for it with a modified storyline. That became Far Cry Instincts.

snippet.textDisplay: My personal favourite game of all-time! The music of this amazing game always brings me back to when I first played it three years ago. When I think about it, I feel bad because I pre-judged it when I got the three pack Deus Ex: Human Revolution, Deus Ex: Invisible War, and Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition. I wanted to play the newest one, but I saw that Deus Ex 1 and Invisible War were before it and even never knew that the first one existed because I thought that Invisible War was first (got it in a video card purchase a long time ago). I decided to play Deus Ex 1 just so I could get to Human Revolution with knowledge of the story and such. Little did I know that I would be playing the best game ever! Invisible War I already knew about and played a little from before, but it never measured up to the experience of Deus Ex 1 because it was really dumbed down, but not TERRIBLE as others perceive it. And to this day, I have not played Human Revolution since I have been playing many other games. I will get to it eventually, but I can still feel relieved and satisfied knowing I played the best installment :)

snippet.textDisplay: @Quiptipt Power of Google. Anyways, Invisible War is the sequel to Deus Ex 1. It starts off twenty years after the first iteration, and takes elements of all three possible endings' events and goes from there. It was hugely panned by critics due to the over-simplified gameplay due to it being released for consoles. I did not find it to be AS bad as critics said, but I did find it underwhelming in some parts. It is not as bad everybody says though, that much is true from my view point as I had enjoyed it still. Just not as much as the first game. Try it out though, you will never know if you will enjoy the game or not if you don't try it! :)

snippet.textDisplay: @CLMisanAcronym I wish they'd recreate the first game with Human Revolution graphics. I still play the first game now and then. Not many games leaves such a great impression. I remember playing it for the first time when it came out like 14 years ago. Even then, the graphics weren't that good, but ok I guess...if you compare it to Half-Life that came out 2 years earlier for instance.  But locations, music, plot etc. made it all up. I remember I played the sequel 11 years ago. I was a bit dissapointed to be honest, but I liked the fact that all 3 endings in the first game had happened. What I disliked was the extremly small levels/maps. You had to go through all these stupid doors that was set up. For instance in the ice on Liberty Island, in Antarctica etc.   Human Revolution blew me away. I hope they will make another game.

snippet.textDisplay: That's just a case of the meaning of a word shifting over time. Like "floppy disks" that haven't been floppy since the 3''1/2 model was introduced, or "solid state disks" that aren't even disks. One of the most extreme examples is the word "gay", that shifted from meaning "happy" to "homosexual" to "pointless".
snippet.textOriginal: That's just a case of the meaning of a word shifting over time. Like "floppy disks" that haven't been floppy since the 3''1/2 model was introduced, or "solid state disks" that aren't even disks. One of the most extreme examples is the word "gay", that shifted from meaning "happy" to "homosexual" to "pointless".

snippet.textDisplay:
The original Deus is arguably the best game I've ever played. I enjoyed HR, but it has absolutely nothing on the original title at all.

As far as mods go, Shifter mixes it up a bit and makes some improvements here and there. HDTP is pretty much an essential these days too.
snippet.textOriginal:
The original Deus is arguably the best game I've ever played. I enjoyed HR, but it has absolutely nothing on the original title at all.

As far as mods go, Shifter mixes it up a bit and makes some improvements here and there. HDTP is pretty much an essential these days too.

snippet.textDisplay:
The plot in DX is tons better. Granted HR was tied down by not really having a villain to focus on (the mercs were lame). I love HR's treatment of Augments more than DX's though. Nano is boring while Jensen's Augs seemed like an evolution of our Desktop/Laptop/Smartphones. I found them a lot more engrossing but Denton's story didn't really focus on trans-humanism.

Gameplay wise it's superior in depth, and it feels more engaging than HR's. Which felt really staged.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly, HR kinda dissapointed me. DX is my favourite game of all time, and I find myself coming back to it again and again. I heard A LOT OF positive hype after HR came out, everyone saying it was as good as the original, so I played it. It was... good. It's one of the best games to come out this year, but it doesn't hold up for even a second when put against THIS gem. I really can't see myself coming back to it, and for me, that means it failed. It was, however, once again, REALLY GOOD.

It's one of the best games to come out this year, but it doesn't hold up for even a second when put against THIS gem. I really can't see myself coming back to it, and for me, that means it failed. snippet.textDisplay: One of the best things about this game for me was that turning to the "Bad guys" actually seemed like a plot twist. In most games when there's a guerilla fighting versus the government, the government is always painfully obviously the bad guys. Here whilst UNATCO seemed pretty bad, the NSF seemed even worse, as though you were fighting for the lesser of two evils. Later on there's Paul's "betrayal", which is genuinely surprising the first time round.

snippet.textDisplay:
I finished Deus Ex two weeks ago.
and man, I enjoyed the game heaps!

Most games decisions carry 'Morality' to them, but this game, you don't know if your decisions are bad and how much weight it will carry. The story was GREAT and I enjoyed the conspiracy theory's. I loved being stealthy and the amount of ways you could complete missions.

Great game!

snippet.textDisplay: I started and stopped this game four times before I finally got into it just this past summer. I'm glad I did finally get into it, as it was one of the most profound gaming experiences that I've had. I actually felt like my decisions had weight to them, unlike the trivial "Morality" systems of other games. Also, the story itself was amazing, namely because of the integration of real-world parallels and far-fetched conspiracy theories.

snippet.textDisplay: I played this game years after its release through Steam, and I loved it. I think this is a game that doesn't leave a great first impression, but when you stick with it after a couple hours you really start getting into it. I can't wait for Human Revolution, hopefully Eidos Montreal does a good job with it, it does seem very good so far from what I've read. I wish they'd get Alexander Brandon to do the music, Michael McCann has some big shoes to fill.
